awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: Distributed Robust Spectrum Sensing and Sharing in Cognitive Radio Networks
awd_abstract_narration: The future Cognitive Radio Networks (CRNs) will consist of heterogeneous devices such as smartphones, tablets and laptops moving dynamically. Accurate and robust spectrum sensing and identification of unauthorized spectrum usage are essential components of spectral efficiency in future radio systems. This project aims to utilize consensus-based cooperation featuring self-organizable and scalable network structure to capture the swarming behaviors of spectrum users and providing cooperative spectrum sensing in a fully distributed manner. By using a combination of control theory and machine learning techniques, the project designs secure weighted average consensus for cooperative spectrum sensing that can not only capture the swarming behaviors in CRNs with heterogeneous devices, but also is robust to practical channel conditions. Robust localization approaches are developed grounded on dynamic signal strength mapping, which have the capability to localize multiple malicious users. Additionally, the new techniques are validated using an actual testbed with on-campus deployment and system demonstration to industrial collaborators. The integration of control theory with dynamic spectrum access will enable a new revolution in the way for enhancing spectrum efficiency in CRNs. The project serves as a pioneer in exploiting multi-disciplinary knowledge (e.g., control systems and machine learning techniques) to achieve a more efficient spectrum usage in future radio systems, aiming to alleviate the increasing crowdness of the spectrum occupancy and support the co-existence of heterogeneous devices. This project also carries out a broad range of education and outreach activities to encourage students to pursue careers in the fields of science and engineering. Research results will be disseminated to academia and industry through presentations and publications in meetings, conferences and journals.

por.por_cntn:
This project builds a framework that performs distributed robust spectrum sensing and sharing to enhance the spectrum efficiency in Cognitive Radio Networks (CRNs). The framework takes the unique view point of utilizing the characteristics of radio propagation and the spatial pattern of received signal energy for (1) developing distributed consensus-based cooperative spectrum sensing, (2) identifying unauthorized spectrum usage, and (3) localizing malicious spectrum users. Such a framework benefits a broad array of applications to facilitate dynamic spectrum access ranging from primary communication detection, to interference avoidance, and to detecting unauthorized users. The proposed framework has resulted in the following major accomplishments.

(1) Distributed Consensus-based Cooperative Spectrum Sensing. To make the distributed spectrum sensing more robust to practical channel conditions and link failures in Cognitive Radio Networks (CRNs), we develop cooperative spectrum sensing based on weighted average consensus. The developed  approach is fully distributed since the combining process only involves local one-hop communication without a centralized fusion center. The weighted combining makes the final decision statistics adaptive with respect to the measurement channel conditions and is robust with respect to communication channel failures and corrupted readings from compromised devices.

(2) Identifying Unauthorized Spectrum Usage. Based on the results from cooperative spectrum sensing, we utilize the characteristics of radio propagation to detect the existence of unauthorized spectrum usage. In particular, the spatial pattern of received signal energy is exploited by multiple spectrum sensors (i.e., secondary users) to collaboratively detect the anomaly. We use machine learning techniques to identify the presence of the unauthorized users under various practical conditions when the (authorized/unauthorized) users are either static or mobile.

(3) Localizing Malicious Spectrum Users. Detecting the presence of unauthorized spectrum usage provides first order information towards defending against malicious spectrum users. Learning the physical location of the malicious users allows us to further exploit a wide range of defense strategies. For instance, one can cope with a reckless secondary user by localizing it and then neutralizing it through human intervention. We develop robust localization approaches grounded the fine-grained channel state information that have the capability to localize multiple unauthorized or malicious users, and are resistant to corrupted signal measurements.

The proposed framework will serve as a pioneer in exploiting multi-disciplinary knowledge (e.g., control-based theory and machine learning techniques) to achieve a more efficient spectrum usage in future radio systems, which aims to alleviate the increasing crowdness of the spectrum occupancy and support the co-existence of heterogeneous devices. Major research results have be disseminated to academia and industry through paper presentations and publications in conferences and journals (e.g., Asia CCS, CNS, TMC, TPDS, and TDSC). The project has enabled two graduate students (one from FSU and the other from Stevens) to collaborate with each other and to gain experience with the challenges of building distributed robust spectrum sensing framework.  The research results have been integrated into both the undergraduate level course "CIS4360 Introduction to Computer Security" and graduate level course "CIS5900 Wireless and Mobile Computing". Moreover, we dismiss and discuss our research findings in the departmental event "CS EXPO" and departmental seminar, where we invite researchers from both academia and industry to give talks about cutting-edge research topics each year. These events enable us to present research findings to students, faculty and experts from industry.
